objectives.title: System Management
objectives.description: Configure and manage storage, kernel modules, network parameters, and virtualization

objectives.title: Security
objectives.description: Apply permissions, configure firewalls, and implement security best practices

objectives.title: Scripting, Containers, and Automation
objectives.description: Create simple shell scripts, manage containers, and understand infrastructure as code

objectives.title: Troubleshooting
objectives.description: Analyze and troubleshoot storage, network, and general system issues

questions.questionText: Which command is used to display the current running processes in Linux?
questions.explanation: The 'ps' command (process status) is used to display information about currently running processes in Linux. Common options include 'ps aux' for detailed information about all processes.

questions.questionText: What is the default location for system log files in most Linux distributions?
questions.explanation: The /var/log directory is the standard location for system log files in Linux. It contains logs from various system services, applications, and the kernel.

questions.questionText: Which command would you use to change file permissions in Linux?
questions.explanation: The 'chmod' (change mode) command is used to change file permissions in Linux. It can use either symbolic (rwx) or numeric (octal) notation to set permissions.

questions.questionText: What does the permission value '755' mean in Linux?
options: Read, write, execute for all users
Read, write, execute for owner; read, execute for group and others
Read, write for owner; read for group and others
questions.explanation: Permission 755 means: owner has read (4), write (2), and execute (1) = 7; group has read (4) and execute (1) = 5; others have read (4) and execute (1) = 5.

questions.questionText: Which file contains user account information in Linux?
questions.explanation: The /etc/passwd file contains user account information including username, user ID, group ID, home directory, and default shell. Actual passwords are stored in /etc/shadow.

questions.questionText: What is the purpose of the shebang (#!) at the beginning of a shell script?
options: It specifies the interpreter to use
questions.explanation: The shebang (#!) at the beginning of a script specifies which interpreter should be used to execute the script, such as #!/bin/bash for bash scripts.

questions.questionText: Which command is used to search for text patterns in files?
questions.explanation: The 'grep' command is used to search for text patterns in files. It can use regular expressions and is one of the most powerful text search tools in Linux.

questions.questionText: What is the purpose of the /etc/fstab file?
questions.explanation: The /etc/fstab (filesystem table) file contains information about disk drives and partitions, defining how and where they should be mounted at system startup.

questions.questionText: Which command displays disk usage for file systems?
questions.explanation: The 'df' (disk free) command displays disk usage information for mounted file systems, showing total space, used space, available space, and mount points.

questions.questionText: What is the default runlevel for a GUI in most modern Linux systems using systemd?
questions.explanation: In systemd-based systems, 'graphical.target' is equivalent to the traditional runlevel 5, providing a multi-user environment with a graphical interface.

questions.questionText: Which command is used to manage systemd services?
questions.explanation: The 'systemctl' command is the primary tool for managing systemd services, allowing you to start, stop, enable, disable, and check the status of services.

questions.questionText: What does SELinux stand for?
questions.explanation: SELinux stands for Security-Enhanced Linux, a security architecture that provides mandatory access control (MAC) for Linux systems.

questions.questionText: Which command would you use to view the last 10 lines of a log file?
questions.explanation: The 'tail -10 logfile' command displays the last 10 lines of a file. This is particularly useful for viewing recent entries in log files.

questions.questionText: What is the purpose of the 'cron' daemon?
options: To schedule and run tasks automatically
questions.explanation: The cron daemon is a time-based job scheduler that runs tasks (cron jobs) automatically at specified times, dates, or intervals.

questions.questionText: Which package manager is used by Debian-based distributions?
questions.explanation: APT (Advanced Package Tool) is the package management system used by Debian and Debian-based distributions like Ubuntu. Common commands include apt-get and apt.

questions.questionText: What command would you use to display network interface configuration?
questions.explanation: Both 'ifconfig' (deprecated but still common) and 'ip addr' (modern replacement) can display network interface configuration. The 'ip' command is preferred in modern distributions.

questions.questionText: Which environment variable contains the directories where Linux searches for executable commands?
questions.explanation: The $PATH environment variable contains a colon-separated list of directories where Linux searches for executable commands when you type a command name.

questions.questionText: What is the purpose of the sudo command?
options: To execute commands with elevated privileges
questions.explanation: The 'sudo' (superuser do) command allows authorized users to execute commands with elevated privileges, typically as the root user, without logging in as root.

questions.questionText: Which command is used to manage Docker containers?
questions.explanation: The 'docker' command is the primary CLI tool for managing Docker containers, images, networks, and volumes in containerized environments.

questions.questionText: What signal does the kill -9 command send to a process?
questions.explanation: The 'kill -9' command sends the SIGKILL signal, which forcefully terminates a process immediately without allowing it to perform cleanup operations.
